reReg 1.1.5
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Visualization of recurrent event data

Produce Cumulative Sample Mean Function Plots

Source: R/plot.R
plotCSM.Rd

Plot the cumulative sample mean function (CSM) for an reSurv object, with more flexible options.

plotCSM(formula, data, onePanel = FALSE, adjrisk = TRUE, control = list(),
  ...)

Arguments

formula

a formula object, with the response on the left of a "~" operator, and the predictors on the right. The response must be a recurrent event survival object as returned by function reSurv.
data

an optional data frame in which to interpret the variables occurring in the "formula".
onePanel

an optional logical value indicating whether cumulative sample means (CSM) will be plotted in the same panel. This is useful when comparing CSM from different groups.
adjrisk

an optional logical value indicating whether risk set will be adjusted. See Details.
control

a list of control parameters.
...

graphical parameters to be passed to methods. These include xlab, ylab and main.

Value

A ggplot object.

Details

When adjrisk = TRUE, the plotCSM is equivalent to the Nelson-Aalen estimator for the intensity function of the recurrent event process. When adjrisk = FALSE, the plotCSM does not adjust for the risk set and assumes all subjects remain at risk after the last observed recurrent event. The argument control consists of options with argument defaults to a list with the following values:

xlab

customizable x-label, default value is "Time".

ylab

customizable y-label, default value is "Subject".

main

customizable title, default value is "Sample cumulative mean function plot".

terminal.name

customizable label for terminal event, default value is "Terminal event".

recurrent.name

customizable legend title for recurrent events, default value is "Recurrent events".

recurrent.types

customizable label for recurrent event type, default value is NULL and .

alpha

between 0 and 1, controls the transparency of points.

The xlab, ylab and main parameters can also be passed down without specifying a control list. See Examples.

See also

reSurv, plot.reSurv

Examples

data(readmission, package = "frailtypack")
plotCSM(reSurv(t.stop, id, event, death) ~ 1, data = readmission)
plotCSM(reSurv(t.stop, id, event, death) ~ sex, data = readmission)
plotCSM(reSurv(t.stop, id, event, death) ~ sex, data = readmission, onePanel = TRUE)
